Class ec.util.PriorityQueue 

java.lang.Object
   |
   +----ec.util.PriorityQueue
public class PriorityQueue
extends Object
As its name implies, PriorityQueue is an implementation of the classic priority queue data structure. All the elements must be instances of Orderable, which forces an object to have a comparison function. The first element is always the one that compares least with respect to the others. (Boy, it'd be nice if Java had parameterized types and better first-class methods!) Note that this class does no synchronization itself; it is safe to call size() and getFirst() without synchronizing, but all inserts and removes must be synchronized if it is possible for a given PriorityQueue to be used from more than one thread.

PriorityQueue()
Construct an empty PriorityQueue, with the default initial capacity-- namely, 50 elements.
PriorityQueue(int)
Construct an empty PriorityQueue, with the given initial capacity.

getFirst()
Get the first element in the queue.
insert(Orderable)
Insert a new element.
removeFirst()
Remove and return the first value in the queue.
size()
Get the current size of the queue.

PriorityQueue 
 public PriorityQueue()
Construct an empty PriorityQueue, with the default initial capacity-- namely, 50 elements.

PriorityQueue 
 public PriorityQueue(int initialCapacity)
Construct an empty PriorityQueue, with the given initial capacity.

Parameters:
initalCapacity - the initial capacity

insert 
 public void insert(Orderable element)
Insert a new element. It is okay to have equal-ordered elements, but the order of retrieval of such elements is arbitrary.

Parameters:
element - the element
getFirst 
 public Orderable getFirst() throws NoSuchElementException
Get the first element in the queue.

Returns:
the first element
Throws: NoSuchElementException
thrown if the queue is empty
removeFirst 
 public Orderable removeFirst() throws NoSuchElementException
Remove and return the first value in the queue.

Returns:
the (former) first element
Throws: NoSuchElementException
thrown if the queue is empty
size 
 public long size()
Get the current size of the queue.

Returns:
the current size of the queue
